newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's Dini sees no risk of EMU delay.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Dini sees no risk of EMU delay.

text.p: Italian Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini said on Saturday he saw no risk of a delay to the planned 1999 start of European Economic and Monetary Union but did not rule out a delay to the decision on who should qualify.
Dini, speaking to reporters at an Anglo-Italian seminar in Venice, said he did not think there was "a risk of delay" to EMU and did not see "signs of delay at the moment".
The single currency is due to be launched on January 1, 1999 and a decision on which states will qualify as founder members is set to be made early next year.
"Towards the end of the year we will be in a position to see whether the decisions on which countries will participate from the start will need to be put back a bit," Dini said.

Italy has pushed through a massive deficit-cutting 1997 budget and plans an extra package of finance measures to try to secure a place at the start of EMU despite fears in Germany that its rocky record on public finances could undermine EMU stability.

Prime Minister Romano Prodi has put his political credibility and that of his centre-left government on the line over Europe. Dini said that to fail to be in the first EMU group "would be a big defeat which we cannot permit ourselves".
Prodi relies on support for a parliamentary majority from the hard-left Communist Refoundation party, which has opposed tax hikes and spending cuts in the forthcoming mini-budget.
But Dini said Europe was so important the government should take measures "with or without the support of Communist Refoundation".
